contentrichtext.text: {{other people|Faulkner|Faulkner (surname)}} Colonel '''Sanford C. 'Sandy' Faulkner''' (1806–1874) was an American<!--From where in America?--> teller of tall tales, fiddle player, and composer of the popular fiddle tune "[[The Arkansas Traveler (song)|The Arkansas Traveler]]", which was the State song of [[Arkansas]] from 1949–1963. Colonel Faulkner served in the [[Confederate Army]] during the [[American Civil War]], and was at one point placed in command of the Arsenal at [[Little Rock, Arkansas]]. The song inspired [[Edward Washburn]] to paint the painting of the same name, which later became a popular [[Currier & Ives]] [[lithograph]]. ==Honors== [[Faulkner County, Arkansas]] is named in honor of Sanford Faulkner. ==External links== *[http://www.floridamemory.com/Collections/folklife/folklife_cd.cfm Recording of the song "Arkansas Traveler" from the 1956 Florida Folk Festival (from the Music from the Florida Folklife Collection Cd, available for public use from the Florida State Archives.)] *{{Find a Grave|19641|accessdate=2009-05-04}} {{Persondata |NAME= Faulkner, Sanford |ALTERNATIVE NAMES= |SHORT DESCRIPTION= Confederate Army officer |DATE OF BIRTH= 1806 |PLACE OF BIRTH= |DATE OF DEATH= 1874 |PLACE OF DEATH= }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Faulkner, Sanford}} [[Category:1806 births]] [[Category:1874 deaths]] [[Category:Confederate States Army officers]] [[Category:American folk musicians]] [[Category:Musicians from Arkansas]] [[Category:People of Arkansas in the American Civil War]] {{US-musician-stub}} {{AmericanCivilWar-bio-stub}}
